channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Macron Meets With Putin; Says Europe Is at a ‘Critical Crossroads’
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France was in Russia to meet with President Vladimir Putin over fears of the Kremlin’s military buildup.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Biden Will Press German Chancellor on Russia Sanctions and Pipeline
item.description: The two leaders are meeting amid concerns that Germany has not been a forceful enough partner in calming tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden will hold his first meeting with Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany.

item.title: Taiwan and China Are Both Closely Watching Ukraine Crisis
item.description: Taiwan knows what it’s like to have an overbearing neighbor. China wonders how forcefully Western powers might react to a Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Amy Qin
item.media:description: A view of the South China Sea last year, with the Chinese city of Xiamen in the distance and the Taiwanese islands of Kinmen in the foreground.

item.title: School Mask Mandate to Be Lifted in New Jersey
item.description: For the first time since the start of the pandemic, New Jersey districts will be permitted to allow students and teachers to stop wearing masks.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey will eliminate a statewide school mask mandate that has been in place since schools reopened in fall 2020.

item.title: After Two Years, Australia to Reopen Borders to Vaccinated Visitors
item.description: Vaccinated tourists, business travelers and all other visa holders will be able to enter Australia later this month. Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Republicans Step Up Attacks on Fauci to Woo Trump Voters
item.description: G.O.P. candidates, tapping into voters’ frustrations with a seemingly endless pandemic, are stepping up their attacks on Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jane Timken, who is running to represent Ohio in the Senate, promises to “advance the Trump agenda without fear or hesitation.”

item.title: Is the Coronavirus in Your Backyard?
item.description: White-tailed deer could become a reservoir for the virus, putting people and animals at risk, health experts say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suresh Kuchipudi, a veterinary microbiologist at Penn State University in State College, Pa., with Cashew, a young white-tailed deer in the university’s deer research center.

item.title: The Tsunami Could Kill Thousands. Can They Build An Escape?
item.description: A major quake in the Pacific Northwest, expected sooner or later, will most likely create waves big enough to wipe out entire towns. Evacuation towers may be the only hope, if they ever get built.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker

item.title: Vincent Zhou of U.S. Is Out of Men’s Figure Skating Event After Covid Test
item.description: Zhou, who missed the end of the team competition after testing positive, also will not join his teammates in accepting his silver medal for that event. Follow live updates.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: In Luge and Skeleton the Goal Is to Go Fast. Just Not Too Fast.
item.description: Technology and safety are colliding in sliding sports, where sleds made for speed are finding tracks built to slow them down.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: Duoyao Fan of China making his way down the track with the Alpine ski course seen in the background during men’s luge training in Yanqing, Beijing.

item.title: Short-Track Speedskating: How It Works and Who’s Worth Watching
item.description: Long-track speedskating is all about grace and efficiency. Short track is often about chaos.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Short track is the cooler, younger sibling of long-track speedskating.

item.title: Ottawa Declares a State of Emergency Amid Trucker Protests
item.description: Protests in Canada over vaccine mandates mushroomed into an occupation of the city and broader demonstrations that have spread beyond the capital. Follow updates here.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Water Supplies From Glaciers May Peak Sooner Than Anticipated
item.description: New satellite mapping of the world’s mountain ice suggests Earth’s glaciers may contain less water than previously thought.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Tourists visited the Perito Moreno Glacier at Los Glaciares National Park in Argentina.

item.title: They Made Millions on Luna, Solana and Polygon: Crypto’s Boom Beyond Bitcoin
item.description: The ranks of cryptocurrency speculators have swelled, with even obscure tokens minting the newly wealthy: at least on the blockchain.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany
item.media:credit: Jussi Puikkonen for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re in some happy country,” said Etienne vantKruys, who bought the cryptocurrency Luna for 20 to 35 cents a token two years ago.

item.title: ‘We Need to Talk About Cosby.’ (Among Others.)
item.description: W. Kamau Bell’s documentary series is a model of how to engage honestly with disgraced artists and their art.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.category: We Need to Talk About Cosby (TV Program)

item.title: How Yiddish Scholars Are Rescuing Women’s Novels From Obscurity
item.description: Works written decades ago, often by female Jewish immigrants, were dismissed as insignificant or unmarketable. But in the past several years, translators devoted to the literature are making it available to a wider readership.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.category: Diary of a Lonely Girl, or the Battle Against Free Love (Book)
A Jewish Refugee in New York (Book)
item.media:description: Miriam Karpilow, the author of “Diary of a Lonely Girl, or the Battle Against Free Love,” in Florida in the late 1940s.

item.title: When the Storming of the Capitol Becomes ‘Legitimate Political Discourse’
item.description: This is one of those weeks when it feels we are doomed to permanent craziness.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:description: “Representatives Cheney and Kinzinger purport to be members of the Republican Party,” an R.N.C. resolution declared on Friday.

item.title: Britain’s Conservatives Enabled Boris Johnson. How Much Will It Cost Them?
item.description: This may be a British story, but the Conservatives’ decision on Johnson’s fate will resonate among many political parties across the democratic world.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Marr
item.media:credit: Simon Dawson/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/Afp Via Getty Images

item.title: Biden’s Misguided Friendship with Mitch McConnell
item.description: The president suffers from the same blind spot as other white liberal leaders throughout history.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: How a Casual Workplace Can Hurt Workers
item.description: The pandemic has eroded many of the formalities of white-collar work — changes that may benefit employers more than their employees.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Spiers

item.title: The Covid Policy That Really Mattered Wasn’t a Policy
item.description: Public health is rooted in the soil of trust.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein

item.title: Older Americans Fight to Make America Better
item.description: We don’t want to leave the world a worse place than we found it.
item.dc:creator: Bill McKibben and Akaya Windwood
item.media:description: Neil Young.

item.title: In Tennessee, the ‘Maus’ Controversy Is the Least of Our Worries
item.description: The new bans are a response to contemporary political forces whose true motivation has nothing to do with books.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl

item.title: Bolsonaro Tried and Failed to Stop Vaccination for Children
item.description: The president’s sabotage efforts have foundered.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Barbara

item.title: How Instagram, FedEx and Wordle Hook You
item.description: The brand architect Debbie Millman says it’s all about design.
item.dc:creator: ‘Sway’

item.title: Who Are We Caring for in the I.C.U.?
item.description: A doctor reckons with what’s owed to a patient’s family members.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: On Whoopi Goldberg’s Comments and the Origins of Racism
item.description: Looking at the history and purpose of race in the modern world.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

item.title: My Trans Journey Through Passport
item.description: A trans woman’s passport photos show more than the countries she has visited.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Finney Boylan
item.media:credit: Illustration by Shoshana Schultz/The New York Times; Photographs courtesy Jennifer Finney Boylan

item.title: I’ll Bet on Susan Collins Over the Resistance
item.description: Some unheroic realism from Republicans might foster the most important response to the events of Jan. 6.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: Get Children Out of ISIS Detention Camps in Syria
item.description: The conditions are horrific and dangerous. And they’re breeding grounds for radicalization and the next generation of ISIS adherents.
item.dc:creator: Peter W. Galbraith
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Boris Johnson Is a Liar
item.description: To help make sense of the scandal surrounding Britain’s prime minister, we enlisted the help of satirical newscaster, Jonathan Pie.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Pie and Adam Westbrook

item.title: How the National Butterfly Center Became the Center of Online Lies
item.description: Becoming the focus of conspiracy theories about child sex trafficking has caused the National Butterfly Center to shut its doors for now.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Gulf Fritillary butterfly at the National Butterfly Center. Conspiracy theorists have spread the falsehood that the refuge is a center of human smuggling and sex trafficking.

item.title: Climate Change Enters the Therapy Room
item.description: Ten years ago, psychologists proposed that a wide range of people would suffer anxiety and grief over climate. Skepticism about that idea is gone.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Commemorates Platinum Jubilee, Marking 70-Year Reign
item.description: The milestone puts the queen, 95, in rarefied company: Only three other monarchs are documented to have reigned for more than 70 years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
George VI, King of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II at Sandringham, her country estate, on Saturday. She plans to spend a quiet Sunday there, with jubilee celebrations scheduled for June.

item.title: Mikaela Shiffrin and Aleksander Aamodt Kilde Are Ski Racing's Power Couple
item.description: The American and Norwegian, each multiple gold medal threats, got serious during the pandemic, as Kilde helped Shiffrin rediscover her love of skiing after her father died.
item.dc:creator: Bill Pennington
item.media:description: Aleksander Aamodt Kilde and Mikaela Shiffrin at the Gold Medal Gala in New York in October.

item.title: Joining the Mile High Club on a Flight with Love Cloud
item.description: Love Cloud, an airplane charter business, offers private flights that help couples take their relationships (and relations) to new heights.
item.dc:creator: Shane O’Neill
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brandon Nguyen kissed his wife Katherin Nguyen before takeoff on a Jan. 15 flight with Love Cloud to celebrate her birthday.

item.title: Why Americans Are Slow to Get Booster Shots
item.description: Why are Americans slow to get booster shots?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Getting a booster shot in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Who Else Is Culpable in George Floyd’s Death?
item.description: Derek Chauvin was sentenced to 22 and a half years for the murder, but what about the other officers who were at the scene?
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Lisa Tobin, Chris Wood, Chelsea Daniel and Marion Lozano
item.media:credit: Aaron Nesheim for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester in January outside the Warren E. Burger Federal Building in St. Paul, Minn., where the trial of the three former officers was taking place.

item.title: Do Democrats Win When They Talk About Race?
item.description: The party in power’s internal debate ahead of the midterms: appeal to moderate swing voters or unite the base against racism?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’

item.title: How to Get Out of Bed and Start Running: Win the ‘Hero’s Minute’
item.description: How do you take that first step out the door? What’s the best way to approach a big running goal? Your training questions, answered.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Mental preparation begins way before the start of any race.

item.title: Syria’s Kurds Wanted Autonomy. They Got an Endless War.
item.description: The Kurds of northeastern Syria dreamed of establishing an autonomous, multiethnic and gender-equal utopia. Instead, their breakaway region has been engulfed in conflict since its creation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands attended the burial of 12 fighters from the Kurdish-led forces who were killed while battling Islamic State militants who took over a prison.

item.title: How the Deaths of N.Y.P.D. Officers Have Shaped Eric Adams
item.description: The mayor’s views on policing are tied in part to his relationships with families of officers killed on the job, as well as with police abuse victims.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times

item.title: Turkey’s Doctors Are Leaving, the Latest Casualty of Spiraling Inflation
item.description: Doctors, worn down by grueling hours and violence, are emigrating in rising numbers, undermining one of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s signature achievements.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of Istanbul. The worsening economy and soaring inflation in Turkey have reduced some doctors’ salaries close to the level of the minimum wage.

item.title: Free Community College Won't Be in Spending Bill, Jill Biden to Say
item.description: In a speech on Monday, the first lady acknowledged that her signature legislative initiative is “no longer” in the Democrats’ spending bill.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jill Biden, a community college professor, had championed access to two-year college, which research shows can lift graduates’ wages.

item.title: Overhaul of Electoral Count Act Will Pass, Manchin Says
item.description: Senators working to overhaul the law said recent revelations about former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election made their work even more crucial.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: The certification of Electoral College votes from Tennessee in 2021. A bill to revise the Electoral Count Act of 1887 would clarify that the vice president has no power to reject a state’s electors.

item.title: Biden Adopts Recommendations for Promoting Union Membership
item.description: Many of the recommendations, proposed by a White House task force, would make it easier for federal workers and employees of contractors to unionize.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:description: President Biden last week signed an executive order requiring wage agreements between labor unions and contractors on federal construction project worth more than $35 million.

item.title: Business Updates: Frontier and Spirit Airlines Announce Plans to Merge
item.description: The budget carriers said they would save $1 billion a year while adding jobs.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Fire Erupts at Brooklyn Building Under Construction
item.description: No injuries were reported, a New York Fire Department spokesman said on Monday. It was unclear whether residents in nearby buildings were required to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor

item.title: 2 Men in Miami Sentenced for Stealing 192 Ventilators Bound for El Salvador
item.description: The crime occurred in the first year of the pandemic, according to U.S. attorneys in Florida, and involved equipment that the U.S. was sending to El Salvador to treat critically ill Covid patients.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: A ventilator in an emergency field hospital. Two men in Miami have been sentenced on charges of stealing 192 ventilators the U.S. was sending to El Salvador in the first year of the pandemic.

item.title: John Vinocur, Foreign Correspondent and Editor, Dies at 81
item.description: After decades as a reporter for The A.P. and The Times, he became executive editor of The International Herald Tribune and a columnist on world affairs.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: John Vinocur in 1987 at the offices of The International Herald Tribune in Paris, where he was executive editor from 1986 to 1996. Before that he was a foreign correspondent for The Associated Press and The New York Times.

item.title: Home Depot Worker Swapped $387,500 in Fake Bills for Real Ones, Officials Say
item.description: The U.S. Secret Service said Adrian Jean Pineda bought prop $100 bills, which are used for entertainment purposes, and swapped them for genuine currency for four years.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: When a Home Depot manager confronted Adrian Jean Pineda, he admitted that he had been swapping the money, according to a complaint.

item.title: Seaman Dies After ‘Hell Week’ of SEAL Training, Navy Says
item.description: Kyle Mullen of Manalapan, N.J., was one of two trainees who were hospitalized after completing several days of training outside San Diego.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mc1 Anthony Walker/U.S. Navy, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Navy SEAL candidates participating in “surf immersion” during basic underwater demolition training in Coronado, Calif., in 2020.

item.title: Looking for Early Warning Signs of Pancreatic Cancer
item.description: Scientists are exploring whether the onset of diabetes may in some cases herald the existence of one of the most deadly of all cancers.
item.dc:creator: Jane E. Brody

item.title: For Successful Aging, Pick Up the Pace or Mix It Up
item.description: Older people who cycled for exercise walked more efficiently than people whose primary exercise is placid walking.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds

item.title: The Secret to Aging Well? Contentment
item.description: Despite having many friends in their 70s, 80s and 90s, I’ve been far too slow to realize that how we respond to aging is a choice made in the mind, not in the gym.
item.dc:creator: Robert W. Goldfarb

item.title: How to Age Gracefully
item.description: Inspired by a new book, “Stupid Things I Won’t Do When I Get Old,” I’m taking stock of my life and deciding what I need to reconsider.
item.dc:creator: Jane E. Brody
item.category: Stupid Things I Won't Do When I Get Old (Book)

item.title: Chaz Guest Returns to New York With a Show Featuring Michael K. Williams
item.description: Chaz Guest, a favorite of Oprah, the Obamas and Angelina Jolie, has a gallery show featuring the actor, who posed just before he died.
item.dc:creator: Ted Loos
item.media:credit: Kendall Bessent for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chaz Guest, artist and Japanophile, at the Vito Schnabel Gallery on Clarkson Street in Manhattan. Based in Los Angeles, he is a former New Yorker who taught himself to paint just a few blocks away.

item.title: ‘Very Cold People’ Makes Something Beautiful Out of a Painful Childhood
item.description: The memoirist Sarah Manguso’s first novel is about a young girl’s life in a small, snowy New England town.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs

item.title: Is Confidence the Secret to Success? Not Exactly.
item.description: Shani Orgad and Rosalind Gill discuss their book, “Confidence Culture,” which challenges the idea sold to women that self-esteem will set them free.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Suzie Howell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shani Orgad, left, and Rosalind Gill, are the authors of “Confidence Culture,” a feminist cultural critique of the marketing around women’s self-esteem.

item.title: Review: City Ballet Gets a Modern Dance Fix
item.description: A new work by the Ailey veteran Jamar Roberts shared a program with revivals by Pam Tanowitz and Kyle Abraham.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: Is My Apartment Building Ready for Fire?
item.description: We spoke with an expert about how residents can keep an eye on their buildings and make sure their homes are safe and up to code.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
